title: alani123
author: alani123
content: El Salvador as a state economy tried to pivot to bitcoin. They employed many tricks to attract investment, to start mining at a scale and bolstered BTC as an alternative currency to the country's population, even recognizing it as legal tender. The tricks failed to materialize. Poverty remained rampant and El Salvador ended up being forced to suspend its Bitcoin program just to take a puny IMF loan. In the end, no crypto entity stepped in to help them when they needed 1.4 billion in USD. We know from Greece's example that IMF measures lead a state economy to disaster. But imagine how desperate a country had to be to accept an IMF intervention over a loan totalling only around 4% of its GDP. Bitcoin didn't shield El Salvador from disruptions in the world economy, it didn't enrich its citizens, it didn't protect it from foreign corporations plundering its resources for cheap etc. So what's the lesson here? Maybe Bitcoin doesn't work at the State level. Yet by Trump's sayings we're going to see the same in the US with a sovereign fund in crypto...

comments.body: Making Bitcoin a Frontline tool to evade economic crisis can be highly unsuccessful especially now that Bitcoin is highly volatile and no one knows the direction the market will go at any time, such a currency or assets can't be dependent on states,  El Salvador's president and government need to focus more on internally producing power that could sustain the El Salvador internal economy while they wait for their Bitcoin reserve funds to make a significant profit that could help the country economy to become more stable as reserves.

But I am surprised that most people and the news I read about it said that El Salvador economy did not improve when the country adopt bitcoin as a legal tender. They are all getting it wrong including you because the economy is not bad than before.Just know that bitcoin served his purpose in El Salvador but IMF is about fiat and the organization is not supporting anything that is not fiat. IMF is not right but El Salvador got no option. If possible the country can do without the loan, bitcoin served its purpose.El Salvador was not a failed experiment.

comments.author: AmoreJaz
comments.created_time: March 04, 2025, 09:57:32 PMLast edit: March 10, 2025, 06:05:34 PM by AmoreJaz
comments.body: I won't say that the early initiatives of El Salvador was a total failed experiment. Do remember, when they first announced about btc being their legal tender, crypto people were being optimistic and enthusiastic about such move. I believe a lot of people also got curious with btc, and in the process, they became crypto users as well. So in my opinion, there were some positive things that have had happened owed to their early initiatives towards bitcoin market.With El Salvador's initiatives, some countries followed thru like Central African Republic. And for sure, there are some positive developments that have happened owed to their move. If not, they can easily go back to their traditional financial system. So for me, there's nothing to worry about El Salvador's change over btc, because they need it to get their loan and that's for their economic survival. After all, the use of btc in this country is not banned but they can continue to use it.

comments.author: Alpha Marine
comments.body: Quote from: alani123 on March 04, 2025, 09:39:00 PM So what's the lesson here? Maybe Bitcoin doesn't work at the State level. The lesson is; bitcoin is simply money that has more value than every other money. Bitcoin is simply a currency that is better than every other currency. I understand it's more technical than this, but in this context, that is what it is. Adopting a new currency doesn't fix every single wrong that's going on in that country. Adopting bitcoin doesn't mean there will be no security issues, inflation, unemployment, etc. Bitcoin is simply money and if you don't work for money you won't get it. Let's say the government has a bitcoin reserve and they make a profit after 10 years, there's no amount of profit bitcoin will give them that can help them eradicate poverty from the country or turn the economy around. They still need to do the needful if they want to have an economy that flourishes. They have to create jobs to battle unemployment. They have to make their environment investor-friendly and make sure citizens have money to patronise foreign investors before foreign investors can come into the country. Adopting bitcoin as legal tender is just one thing out of a long list of things that they need to do. Unfortunately, the body (IMF) that's supposed to help them grow sees things differently from them and has its own agenda.

comments.author: Majestic-milf
comments.body: If El Salvador is a failed project, what then would we say of Central African Republic? It's kinda funny how it seems like no one is talking about them and focusing all their attention on El Salvador.We should not fault Nayib's over-excitement over the prospect of including Bitcoin as a means of payment in their country but I guess it's his over ambitiousness that brought him to this point. Just as the others have said, you can't solely rely on BTC to revive a failed economy because after the whole dust have settled down from the announcement of being the first country to accept Bitcoin as legal tender, the challenge of making it work lies in wait.I feel that El Salvador were too in a hurry to heed the advice of the IMF that's why they had to discontinue use of BTC since they needed financial aid do badly.

comments.author: franky1
comments.body: el salvador had a bitcoin reserve and still does.. so no failure thereIMF said to stop accumulating bitcoin (4th march 2025) and do so by december 2025.. and el salvador decided to buy 5btc more yesterday.. so seems like el savador didnt drop their bitcoin reserve instantly, but instead add to itel salvador is still buying for its bitcoin reserve, still mining,.. now for the complicated controversies:el salvador made bitcoin legal tender in summer 2021, but instead of actually offering a software app to its citizens that actually involved the bitcoin network and bitcoin transactions... they were(my word/my opinion) "conned" into playing around with a non bitcoin network (LN to be exact) as the backbone of its chivo wallet from autumn 2021.and yes the LN advocates that helped chivo set up chivo backbone of its system, pretended LN was bitcoin..  and yes by spring 2022 LN failed to do its job for el salvadorians.  so again bitcoin didnt fail but LN pretending to be bitcoin failedso with not many el salvadorians actually using bitcoin. there was not much loss to changing things from a mandatory payment option of retailers accepting chivo payments, alongside dollar, to now be a voluntary option,,(many retailers refused to continue using chivo from 2022 anyway)el salvador is continuing to deal with bitcoin via mining and the reserve, but doing it in a different way than the con artists they invited in 2021 whom conned them into LN services..lets wait for the bitcoin 2025 ATH in autumn-winter.. and then see how el salvador responds to the IMF in december...

comments.author: OgNasty
comments.body: I think it's a bit early to call El Salvador a failed experiment.  It showed that people really do like digital payment technology, but are still hesitant to use Bitcoin.  Stablecoins are doing great in El Salvador though and chains like Tron have thrived.  I think that shows promise for other high usage chains like Solana and also shows that people don't want to use the Lightning Network.  The crypto economy continues to develop and I think people would be wise to look at what happened in El Salvador and why the people are using the currency and chains that they are.

comments.author: Darker45
comments.body: El Salvador is being ran using the the fiat standard, not the Bitcoin standard. Moreover, it is subject to the global fiat standard, not the Bitcoin standard. Just because the country embraced Bitcoin as an alternative doesn't mean it will turn its condition around all of a sudden. Bitcoin isn't a magic wand, a silver bullet. But it can't be denied that certain people, families, have improved conditions after adopting Bitcoin. On the other hand, however, any country shouldn't fall to the exaggerations, or perhaps scams, of Bitcoin maxis that Bitcoin adoption would turn countries from frogs to princes.

comments.author: Minor Miner
comments.created_time: March 05, 2025, 03:17:14 AMLast edit: March 05, 2025, 04:14:03 AM by Minor Miner
comments.body: Quote from: _act_ on March 04, 2025, 09:49:06 PMEl Salvador has been in dept before the country made bitcoin a legal tender. Neither was the country had good economy as if something changes. Not that El Salvador was perfect before but bitcoin still helped in some areas like increasing in tourism as bitcoin made El Salvador to be a tourists attraction. But I am surprised that most people and the news I read about it said that El Salvador economy did not improve when the country adopt bitcoin as a legal tender. They are all getting it wrong including you because the economy is not bad than before.As far as I know, El Salvador's economy had been struggling for decades before Nayib Bukele took office and since he took office, the economy has improved significantly but is still not completely out of trouble.  Tourism is considered one of El Salvador's strengths and contributes up to 15% to the country's GDP, and since bitcoin became legal tender, their tourism industry has increased by 30% in 2022. So it can be said that bitcoin has contributed to the improvement of their economy over the years. But what people are spreading is that they think El Salvador's bitcoin investment has been a huge success and that this is the main factor that saved El Salvador's economy. But in fact, the main factor that has helped El Salvador's economy improve rapidly over the years is thanks to Nayib Bukele's economic policies. He has improved the crime and gang situation, seen as the biggest problem causing economic instability in the country, sought to attract foreign investors and promote the country's strengths such as remittances and agriculture...It can be said that the greatest credit belongs to Nayib Bukele with his economic policies, not just relying on bitcoin investment to save the economy as many people mistakenly think.QuoteEl Salvador was not a failed experiment.It is considered a failure because people had too high expectations for bitcoin and thought that bitcoin is a magic wand that can save any economy just by adopting it.

comments.author: Fiatless
comments.body: Quote from: alani123 on March 04, 2025, 09:39:00 PMEl Salvador as a state economy tried to pivot to bitcoin. They employed many tricks to attract investment, to start mining at a scale and bolstered BTC as an alternative currency to the country's population, even recognizing it as legal tender. The tricks failed to materialize. Poverty remained rampant and El Salvador ended up being forced to suspend its Bitcoin program just to take a puny IMF loan. In the end, no crypto entity stepped in to help them when they needed 1.4 billion in USD. We know from Greece's example that IMF measures lead a state economy to disaster. But imagine how desperate a country had to be to accept an IMF intervention over a loan totalling only around 4% of its GDP. Bitcoin didn't shield El Salvador from disruptions in the world economy, it didn't enrich its citizens, it didn't protect it from foreign corporations plundering its resources for cheap etc. So what's the lesson here? Maybe Bitcoin doesn't work at the State level. Yet by Trump's sayings we're going to see the same in the US with a sovereign fund in crypto... You seem to have a totally wrong perspective about El Salvador's Bitcoin policy. The project was not designed to lift the country out of a financial mess, neither was it paraded as a means to shield El Salvador from IMF loans. The country has been in bad shape and Nayid Bukele is trying to fix it. He managed to reduce the crime rate of the country, which was its major problem. Bitcoin was just a program designed to diversify the economy of El Salvador. Don't also forget that El Salvador is the first country to make Bitcoin a legal tender, so they made some mistakes because they were doing some experiments. Other countries can learn from the mistakes of El Salvador and improve on them. Now, we should also take note that a President would always make hard decisions when there is an emergency. Bukele taking a loan from the IMF and readjusting the Bitcoin policy is not a bad move if the economy needs the money. Afterall the country didn't sell any of its hodling and it is still buying more coins. El Salvador is a pride of the Bitcoin ecosystem and should be appreciated for being bold enough to be the first country to make Bitcoin a legal tender.
